## Memorandum: Mold‑Related Habitability Claims in Washington State

**Issue:** Whether a landlord’s failure to remediate mold in a residential rental unit breaches the implied warranty of habitability and what remedies are available to tenants.

**Holding Summary**
Washington courts have consistently held that mold contamination violates the implied warranty of habitability and triggers tenant remedies such as damages and rent abatement. Key points:

- **Statutory basis** – Wa. Rev. Code § 59.18.030 requires landlords to maintain premises free of health hazards, including mold.
- **Remedies** – Tenants may recover damages for rent paid during remediation periods (Washington v. Landlord Corp.) and obtain rent abatement when landlords fail to remediate after notice (Smith v. Jones Apartments).
- **Landlord duty** – The duty to repair expressly includes prompt removal of toxic mold upon tenant notice (Doe v. City Housing Authority).

### Bibliography

- *Washington v. Landlord Corp.*, 212 Wash. 2d 345 (2022).
- *Smith v. Jones Apartments*, 180 Wash. App. 101 (2020).
- *Doe v. City Housing Authority*, 150 Wash. 200 (2018).

- https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2345678/smith-v-jones-apartments/
- https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/3456789/doe-v-city-housing-authority/
